addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord,
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

17 Julij
1591
. M
r
Bodeleie to my L. The trewe report of
e Overthrowe of certaine of
e
D. Parmas
House./

page.lettertext:
fol.228r
May it please yo
r
good L. I have signified in
a former,
e 14 of this moneth,
e good successe
of o
r
exploit against
e Enemies horse. But I
writte
at letter to yo
r
L. before o
r
troupes were
all returned: for w
ch
I could not write w
t
certaintie, nor specificie so muche, as came after
to my knowledge. For where I writte but of
three of their Cornets, that were defeated, they
are found to be six. The first was
e Cor-
net of
e Dukes garde: of w
ch
e Captaine
Pedro Francesco de Nicelli
is taken prisoner:
who commaunded by provision over all the
horsemen: also his cornet was taken, and the
Dukes own collours. The 2 was
e com-
pany of
Alfonso Davales
bastard brother to
e
Marquis of Guasto
, who is likewise prisoner,
w
t
his cornet and collours. The 3 of
Hie-
ronymo Carraffa
, who had
e company of the
Marquis of Guasto. His Lieutenant il
Conte
Decio de Manfredi
is prisoner, and his Cornet
w
t
his collours are taken. The 4 of Biasco
Capozuceli
brother to
Cosimo
Secretary to the
Duke. These 4 were Italians: but
e 5 was
Pradiglia
an old Spanishe Captaine, who was
brought into Arnham prisoner, but died the
same day of his woundes. The 6 of
Antonio
d'Aguay
, who had a Spanishe company of Har-
que buziers. There were also taken pri-
soners,
Captaine Jacomo
, heeretofore a Captaine
of footemen, but nowe in
e Dukes intertenment.
Likewise
Captaine Galeazzo del Pozzo
sometime
Cornet of Appio Conte, and nowe intertened by
Hieronymo Caraffa. These are
e chief of
those that were taken, but there are many
other officers and gentlemen of qualitie prisoners.
The nomber of them all I can not certifie pre-
sicely: but as farre as I can learne, they are
towardes a 100 and 240 horses.
fol.228v
Their horses were no better then o
rs
, theire horsemen
notw
t
standing were farre better armed: and most
of them old and very talle souldiers,
e floure, as is
thought, of all his horsemen. They receaved no
great hurt in conflict w
t
e footmen: but when
they came in sight of their pykes, they made a sod-
daine halt, having had before o
r
horse in chase,
and being come to
e point to do execution. And
then o
r
horsemen, had
e leasure to recover them-
selves, and to charge
e Enemie a freshe, w
ch
put
them presently in route. This was done
e 14
day, and
e morning after
e Enemies campe was
full of fires: w
ch
was taken for a token of their
soddaine departure. Many upon it were sent
abroade, both horse and foote, pesants and others, to
learne w
at
was meant: and certaine trompetters
were dispatched w
t
counterfait errandes, to aske
after prisoners. But by
e Enemies forsight all
e
advenues of his campe, w
ch
were very fewe, were
diligently garded, and all commers in so streightly
detened,
at we continued alwaies doubtfull
whether his fires were but strategemes, to bring
us onward, or that his meaning were otherwise,
directly to be gone. Nevertheles
e next day
after there were
at sent us worde from neutral
places, that for certaine his forces were in trans-
porting to
Nieumeghen
side: wherupon there
were 3000 footemn, and 700 horse sent thi-
therward, who approched so neere to
e Enemies
campe, as they forced a
corps de garde
w
t
in
their trenches, and might easely discerne that
thay had divers of their footmen in order of bat-
tel, upon
e waters side. O
r
troupes remained
there for
e space of two houres together, but per-
ceaving that
e Enemie was unwilling to
come to
blowes,
and finding no securitie in assaulting their trenches,
being also uncertaine, howe many of his campe
were passed
e river,
ei returned homewarde
fol.229r
that night. Howbeit this morning we had a letter
sent hither from out of
e sconce, whereby we were
assured, that
e greatest pa rt of his troupes were
already gone over. Againe therupon we sent
thither
e like forces, as
e day before: but founde
no enemie when
ei came. For all their campe
was lodged in sight, on
e other side, of
e Wael.
What they purpose to doe next, we can not yet
conjecture. It is said by o
r
prisoners, and we
have it otherwise by other intelligence, that they
goe undoubtedly for
Fraunce.
But yet we
are persuaded, that untill
e Duke be assured
what way will be taken by
e Germaine Levie,
he will keepe in these quarters. Yesterday
there came
Verdugo
unto him, w
t
all his forces
of
Friseland:
but whether his mutins of
Diest
and
Herentals
have receaved contentment
we knowe not. The whole assembly
of
e general states is newly come hither from
e
Hage:
but I doe not yet heare for what occasio
n.
It shall be signified in my next, w
t
o
r
next reso-
lution for
e imploiment of o
r
forces.
And so
I take my humble leave. From Arnham
July 17 1591.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
